sigir-20141.raw: A 58-year-old African-American woman presents to the ER with episodic pressing/burning anterior chest pain that began two days earlier for the first time in her life. The pain started while she was walking, radiates to the back, and is accompanied by nausea, diaphoresis and mild dyspnea, but is not increased on inspiration. The latest episode of pain ended half an hour prior to her arrival. She is known to have hypertension and obesity. She denies smoking, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, or a family history of heart disease. She currently takes no medications. Physical examination is normal. The EKG shows nonspecific changes.

gpt-4-turbo.summary: 58-year-old African-American woman with episodic chest pain, hypertension, and obesity.
conditions: chest pain with normal physical exam
chest pain with nonspecific EKG changes
chest pain without family history of heart disease

sigir-20142.raw: An 8-year-old male presents in March to the ER with fever up to 39 C, dyspnea and cough for 2 days. He has just returned from a 5 day vacation in Colorado. Parents report that prior to the onset of fever and cough, he had loose stools. He denies upper respiratory tract symptoms. On examination he is in respiratory distress and has bronchial respiratory sounds on the left. A chest x-ray shows bilateral lung infiltrates.

gpt-4-turbo.summary: 8-year-old male with fever, dyspnea, cough, and bilateral lung infiltrates, recently traveled to Colorado, with preceding loose stools.
